issues.title: reevaluate use of Context IDs
issues.author: marten-seemann
issues.body: Context IDs allow a zero-overhead encoding of the ECN bits (provided the client chooses values that can be encoded as a 1-byte QUIC varint). However, it's not clear how one would use this extension with CONNECT-UDP Listen, which uses context IDs to define compression contexts.

comments.author: marten-seemann
comments.body:
Alternatively, we could define that negotiating the extension adds a single byte at the beginning of the datagram, no matter which context ID is used.

This would add an overhead of 1 byte. Of this first byte, we'd leave 6 bits undefined, so that future extensions could use them without incurring any overhead.

comments.author: marten-seemann
comments.body:
> Alternatively, we could define that negotiating the extension adds a single byte at the beginning of the datagram, no matter which context ID is used.

This doesn't work when optimistically sending DATAGRAMs, prepending a payload byte is not safe until the extension has been negotiated.

issues.title: elaborate on context ID usage when optimistically sending packets
issues.author: marten-seemann
issues.body:
This is when sending DATAGRAMs right after sending the CONNECT request, before receiving the proxy's response.

Options:
* play it safe: only use context ID 0
* optimistically send DATAGRAMs with non-zero context IDs: worst case scenario these packets are getting dropped (and the rejection of the extension is an explicit signal to retransmit these packets, if desired)
